OccamsRazor

I saw this article over on the beeb and thought it was quite thought provoking:
 
 
'I survived an abortion attempt' 
 
 Gianna Jessen's mother was seven-and-a-half months pregnant when it was decided to abort the foetus she was carrying. 
 
 A saline solution was injected into Gianna's mother's womb, which doctors thought would kill the foetus within hours. 
 
 This time, most unusually, the procedure failed and Gianna was born alive, thanks in part to a shocked nurse. 
 
 She was so taken aback by Gianna's live delivery that she summoned an ambulance to whisk her from the abortion clinic to the hospital. 
 
 She weighed only two pounds at birth and needed to stay in hospital for nearly three months. 
 
 In an ironic twist of fate the abortionist had to sign her birth certificate. 
 
 Now American-born Gianna, aged 28, is in London to give her message against abortion.

 
 Opinions?

post_info.post_title: Speaking against abortion: the unusual perspective of Gianna Jessen

Sigma

Opinions?

 
 Wow. A very unusual and distressing story, and probably why saline abortions are no longer used.
 
 It is very unfortunate for her to have to live with that disability.
oliphant

It didn't work? Well, her mom should have just left her in the woods to die. I hear that one's pretty surefire.
 
 In all honesty, there is nothing distressing about this story. More people die in their heroic charge through the womb than from charging up every hill in historical war, combined. Even though the hill's got pill boxes and machine guns, after a few million, at least some lucky few are bound to scrape past. She just happens to be one.
Bassman

Wow. A very unusual and distressing story, and probably why saline abortions are no longer used.
 
 It is very unfortunate for her to have to live with that disability.

 What disability? The fact that she survived a murderous attempt on her life?

What disability? The fact that she survived a murderous attempt on her life?

 
 I read the linked article.
 
 
She has cerebral palsy as a direct result of the procedure carried out on her in the womb.

 I've not found any reference to legality- although if the proceedure had not been performed within the law I'd explect the pro-lifers would seize on that issue and exploit it to the full.

 I would rather take life with a disability over death any day.

 In all honesty, there is nothing distressing about this story. More people die in their heroic charge through the womb than from charging up every hill in historical war, combined. Even though the hill's got pill boxes and machine guns, after a few million, at least some lucky few are bound to scrape past. She just happens to be one.

 
 Correct. This is a story of survival.

Surely it would be more of an argument for the pro-choice side: if we ban it this sort of thing will happen, backstreet abortions etc.

 good point, no one can argue with that comment.
OccamsRazor

Surely it would be more of an argument for the pro-choice side: if we ban it this sort of thing will happen, backstreet abortions etc.

 
 Yes that is correct, which goes to show this case can be used to argue both for and against abortion.
 
 With regard to the legality issue, if it were had had been carried out illegally it is the sort of point I could see the pro-lifers seizing on to show how current restirctions on abortion are inadequate and only full scale criminalisation of the practice would serve as sufficent protection.
